"Steve, I'm assuming that the model started as an XML Schema and that xsd:date was mapped to XMLTypePackage.getDate: /** * Returns the meta object for data type '{@link java.lang.Object Date}'. * * * @return the meta object for data type 'Date'. * @see java.lang.Object * @model instanceClass="java.lang.Object" * @generated */ EDataType getDate(); Since that type is declared to be java.lang.Object (to hide the internal implementation class that will eventually be replaced by XMLGregorianCalendar) assigning a java.util.Date to the feature will not be noticed as a type error. And since the serialization is done like this: public String convertDateToString(EDataType eDataType, Object instanceValue) { return instanceValue == null ? null : instanceValue.toString(); } the java.util.Date object is converted to a String okay, but not to a form that conforms to xsd:date. One way to "fix" this would be to check for java.util.Date in the above method and serialize it in a way that conforms to xsd:date (as does the EDate type in the Ecore package), but that's kind of a hack, and code that relies on this will break when java.lang.Object becomes XMLGregorianCalendar and java.util.Date may not longer be assigned. A better way to handle this is for setDate and getDate to do conversion to and from other "Date" types. In this case, it would convert the Date to our internal XMLCalendar and back. (It would probably be nice and consistent for getString and setString to work for dates too, but 1.0 didn't specify that.) The ideal solution for this particular scenario would be for the xsd:date to have mapped to the less precise EDate type in Ecore rather than the 100% precise Date type in XMLType, but I think we should leave changes to the mapping to be based on the 1.1 spec, not to fix 1.0 problems."
